msg: A Special Interest Group focused on bringing stakeholders together to look at climate related use cases, such as using Hyperledger frameworks to build a global and open climate accounting system that will help achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement (the United Nation's global climate accord).
User User_1 added by dhuseby.
MartinWainstein
Has joined the channel.

Hi @all my name is Martin Wainstein, and I'll be chairing this SIG alongside Tom Baumann. I run the Yale Open Innovation Lab, and climate finance projects at the Digital Currency Initiative at the MIT Media Lab. We actively work on climate across the whole scope and have been working closely with Hyperledger in recent months. Will be updating the wiki and mailing list soon. Great to have this launched and looking forward to some great discussions happening here!

Can anyone remember who posted the whitepaper "A DID for Everything" in the Zoom chat on the 11th. I have just read through it. The idea that lieterally everyhting can have an ID and that the provenance of data can be verified transparently will be extremely importnant when accounting for actions on planetary scale. The way in which DADs are namespacible also present

Can anyone remember who posted the whitepaper "A DID for Everything" in the Zoom chat on the 11th. I have just read through it. The idea that literally everyhting can have an ID and that the provenance of data can be verified transparently will be extremely important when accounting for actions on planetary scale. The way in which DADs are namespacible also present a lot of opportunities for standarisation

Can anyone remember who posted the whitepaper "A DID for Everything" in the Zoom chat on the 11th. I have just read through it. The idea that literally everyhting can have an ID and that the provenance of data can be verified transparently will be extremely important when accounting for actions on planetary scale. The way in which DADs are namespacible also present a lot of opportunities for standarisation. A standard for the way in which we identify data, data sources, data processors and curators within the context of climate change  mitigation and adaptation could be something that this group can work on that can benefit a lot of the work many of us are already doing
a lot of opportunities
for standardisation

Zoom chat is great for certain things. In meetings, rocket chat is preferred over zoom chat because of greater transparency and persistence. Zoom chat is integrated and immediate, but disappears- can be recovered after the call, when recording-
This is probably what you are talking about ... https://github.com/SmithSamuelM/Papers/blob/master/whitepapers/A_DID_for_everything.md
I have some different views on this .. you might want to check out https://dev.w3.org/2008/video/mediaann/ReSpec.js/documentation.html
and this video that contrasts Public and Peer DIDs
https://youtu.be/EKH7vjp_P9o

Thanks for the links. I still have to think through the implications of the distintion between public and privte DID in the context on climate change mitigation and adaptiation projects. I struggle to see the connection between ReSpec.js and DIDs / DADs - maybe you can elucidate

you may want to look over the Trust over IP RFC in Hyperledger Aries ... https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-rfcs/tree/master/concepts/0289-toip-stack

We see this as the emerging stack for trustworthy data exchange. 

I believe that the most important packaging of data will be in Layer 3 of the stack ... a key one being Verifiable Credentials (a W3C data format standard). These will be the things that allow us to create trustworthy representations of constructs like a GHG Emmission profile. This is what we can "count". Then we can construct accounting systems that are able to track these constructs. Quite analagous to money and accounting practices.

DIDs will be a lower level construct that machines largely deal with. DIDs for public issuers and Peer DIDs to faciliate the DIDComm procotol at layer 2.

Have a look and see what you think. Happy to answer questions.
If you would like to see the deeper levels of the protocols check out the Aries Interop Profile 1.0.0 at https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-rfcs/tree/master/concepts/0302-aries-interop-profile

We are the maintainers of Aries-Cloudagent-Python which implements the 1.0.0 Aries Interop Profile along with few other implementions noted in RFC 0302.

https://github.com/hyperledger/aries-cloudagent-python

Hello Everyone - Tom Baumann, CA2 SIG co-chair.

Dear CA2 SIG Colleagues,
The ITU.int is registration open and a call for experts for three working groups within the ITU Focus Group on Environmental Efficiency for AI and Emerging Technologies (eg Blockchain), which is within the ITU Study Group 5 on Environment, Climate Change and Circular Economy. The WG meetings are Sep 28, 29, 30 at 2pm Geneva time - https://www.itu.int/en/ITU-T/focusgroups/ai4ee/Pages/default.aspx.
Best, Tom

Dear CA2 SIG Colleagues,

The WG meetings are Sep 28, 29, 30 at 2pm Geneva time - https://www.itu.int/en/ITU-T/focusgroups/ai4ee/Pages/default.aspx.
Best, Tom

Adding CA2SIG Members

Hello all,  my name is Peter Clarke, and I'll be chairing this SIG alongside Robin and Sherwood.  I put together a blockchain startup about 5 years ago with alumni from LSE IDEAS at the London School of Economics called Affine. Our mission was to develop  projects that would address global challenges by using emerging technologies. This started with Fabric v0.6 and connecting with central banks on 8 May 2016. Great to participate in CASIG and looking forward to serve the CASIG community! Peter
Great @peterinwestend Congratulations to Robin, Sherwood ... Looking forward great CA2SIG community building

@knagware9 @Sichen Hello, my name is Robert Jameson and I am a member of the Climate Action SIG. I structured a securitisation transaction that I wanted to post but the wiki is giving me guff about "no permissions"
I can post it here if you could mail it to our members. We also provisioned a Blockchain network for securitisation and I would be honoured if @VipinB from Cap Markets would lend his gravitas ..
Thank you.

Hi Robert, the wiki is open to editing for everyone with a valid Linux Foundation ID. Check the following link to get ready https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/CASIG/Contribution+Opportunities#ContributionOpportunities-sign-in-sign-up 
If you're still not able to edit the wiki after the steps mentioned in the link please text me.
@RobinKlemens Thank you . I posted a first draft of the business overview of a transaction structure. Colleagues will address SDLC workflows.

@RobinKlemens Hi, Robin 
I'm working to modify https://github.com/opentaps/blockchain-carbon-accounting/tree/main/utility-emissions-channel/docker-compose-setup
to run it with external chaincode service, I've modified core.yaml, set
externalBuilders:
  - name: external-builder
    path: /builders/external

and I've put build, detect and release scripts into the /builders/external path on the peer container, i.e. everything similar to the aws kubernetes deployment,
but attempt to install chaincode says 'Unknown chaincodeType: EXTERNAL'
Are there any other parameters should be set to allow install external chaincode ?
Hello @knagware and @robin @KonstantinRybalko
Are you ready to try 'joining another network' ?  I set up a starter kit using Fabric 1.495 which will crash you channel if you have upgraded to 2.0+
*your
Or ask you to join my network  - to swap tokens

Is there more info on your Blockchain network for securitisation? Please post any publicly available info

- `core.yaml`
- `docker-compose-file-you-use-for-the-peer.yaml`
- `build-scripts-dir`
thx, Robin

What application are currently running on top of your network?
thx, Robin

@VipinB Yes, there is more information on the securitisation network posted on the CASIG wiki in Draft Form. We will provide you with a link to V2.  The structure is a hybrid multi-seller, 'cascading' or 'waterfall'  variable note programme.  This will start with a traditional warehousing line, This V2 will be posted to the CASIG group but I will ensure you are provided an extra link in the abundance of  caution.  ETA 12 hours. Thank you, Robert
@RobinKlemens Robin, thank you for your informative response. We had a team meeting this morning and elected not to upgrade the Securitisation Blockchain to 2.2.1
We are operating  an IBM Cloud Blockchain network  equivalent to HL  Fabric V.1.4+

By 'participating organisations' I assume you mean collaborators rather than organisations org1 org2. The answer to the first question is we are not collaborating yet with another team or organisation.  The second question - org1 and org2  orderer1 using Kafka and the application lawyer is 'Securitizaton' .
My role is Business Requirements Analysis not Solutions Architecture. I will pass your comments and questions at handover to India about 2.2.1.
I heard your meeting went very well yesterday. Congratulations.
The application layer or chaincode is Securitisation of power purchase contracts from renewable energy projects .  Thank you.

@KonstantinRybalko Where is the `core.yaml`file you edited?
Also I cannot see a volumes mount in `docker-compose-carbonAccounting.yaml` which mounts the `core.yaml`.
Mount the `core.yaml` file to the following location:
```/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer # env | grep "FABRIC_CFG_PATH"
FABRIC_CFG_PATH=/etc/hyperledger/fabric
/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer # ls -l /etc/hyperledger/fabric
total 36
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root         33378 Sep 30 18:39 core.yaml
drwx------    9 root     root           288 Mar 24 06:32 msp
drwx------   12 root     root           384 Mar 24 06:32 tls```

I suggest you copy the `core.yaml` from https://github.com/opentaps/blockchain-carbon-accounting/blob/main/multi-cloud-deployment/fabric-config/core.yaml and rename the folder `./configtx` to `./fabric-config` and then also put the `core.yaml` there

Thanks for forwarding my questions.
As long as we don't run the fabric networks at the same version, we cannot "merge" our networks.
However, I suggest you take a look at https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/tree/main/multi-cloud-deployment
That's our current configuration. We'll launch the network soon with three organizations. Each organization will host it's own fabric-ca, 1 orderer, and at least 1 peer

Can you provide a link to your GitHub? Maybe it could also be an option for you to present your setup and chaincode in the next peer programming session on Monday
https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/CASIG/Carbon+Accounting+and+Certification+Working+Group

@RobinKlemens Good morning Robin.  I am reading notes on handovers during the night. OK 1. No, v. 1.4 Fabric is not compatible with 2.0+   2.  Leave the Securitisation Blockchain at the Multi-Channel Level  3.  Peter (me) to provision new blockchain v 2.0 + testnet .
@RobinKlemens I took a quick look at Github and the Emissions Token Network has 2 organizations which appear to be auditors.
@RobinKlemens Thank you. I've made those changes. It worked. I was able install external chaincode. Continue working on the modifications to use it.

Correct. This is the configuration of the current setup for local testing. However, once we move to a production-ready system, more organizations will host the network (at least 3). If the act as auditors is not decided yet
Glad to hear that!! Thanks for your contribution!!! :hyperledger:

@RobinKlemens I am in heated agreement!  Once you start to get to>15 organisations on Fabric, performance starts to degrade dramatically across all metrics. Latency, throughput, and the data validation pipeline. We can discuss at the peer programming meeting  1. Separating transaction data from metadata so that only transaction ID is needed to determine the transaction order 2) cache unmarshalled blocks at the committer  and 3. use a hash table for state storage are reliable approaches to actually improve performance. What we used was not really a consensus algorithm as Kafka+ Zookeeper never proved a bottleneck.

@Robinklemens on Besu, that degrades at the atomic cross chain .  This eThaler design is different as it is not ERC20. Thank you . Plan is to set up network to trade 'tokens (Account UXTO in our case) with main emissions channel.
@PeterCLARKE Handover. It looks to me like we can try a test with @SiChen and @RobinKlemens to 'trade' tokens.
@PeterCLARKE I will post to the Wiki my next draft of the securitisation document, handover to India and update the MURAL.
Thanks, I will take a look, maybe you can discuss how we can take this forward including a presentation in the CMSIG about securitization

As said, we start with three organizations and I think it will take a long time (if ever) that we cross the number of 15 organizations. 
Since Fabric v. 2.x, Kafka and Zookeeper are deprecated. Also, Kafka only works properly within one Kubernetes cluster. We run the network in three different and independent clusters. 
Fabric 2.2 LTS uses a Raft-based consensus algorithm.

In terms of chaincode performance, it would definitely make sense to review the chaincode `emissionscontract.js` 
If you could review the code and post your recommendations to GitHub in the form of issues, that would be great. 
https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/blob/main/utility-emissions-channel/chaincode/node_ext/index.js

What are the pro and cons of using eThaler (EIP 1155 or EIP 20) vs. UXTO (ERC20) token? Having a list of arguments for each solution could help the group to decide on the most suitable token implementation
@RobinKlemens Morning.
I do not agree about 15 orgs but it is irrelevant .
The reason is that Fabric can be reconfigured to workaround the bottleneck.

The above link is a film of a Sumatran tiger being released back into the wild. It is a message that biodiversity has value.  This was in Indonesia
@lewislinford @Drraghavendra99 @RobinKlemens The finance use case
Is a network for Sukuk bonds and other Shari'a financings.   https://blossomfinance.com/posts/sukuk-on-blockchain-a-legal-regulatory-and-shariah-review
Both Indonesia and Malaysia are of the Muslim Faith . Thus the structure should be appropriate
These documents will be in our wiki along with a securitisation document from Robert .
Great to see all these conversations and new members joined group

@PeterCLARKE how do you think these documents fit into the mission of the CA2SIG? https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/CASIG/Climate+Action+and+Accounting+SIG+Home
The use cases sound very interesting. However, I'm not sure if the Hyperledger Climate SIG is the right place for them. Yes, biodiversity has value to climate but I think more on a global scale than based on species like the Sumatran tiger.

@RobinKlemens Excellent point about "biodiversity having value to the climate ...on a global scale"   .  I see this identification of value as within scope of the Climate SIG , through the work of Nova.org (Christian) OS Climate (Tom, Martin) . The video of the tiger was to welcome new members joining from Indonesia and Malaysia.
A story about the Black Forest (and the acid rain from RWE) or the English countryside, California Coast, are other examples of the global value of these fragile ecosystems.

What we are doing here is we are using the video. The video is a human interest story to welcome new members to personalise our own experience with climate change we want to share the message that computer sience is alot more inclusive than people think.
Professor Anita Lundberg would be a great value to the community.

@PeterCLARKE @lewislinford - I've got to agree with @RobinKlemens Peter and Lewis. It is important to keep our content and discussions related to the scope of the SIG. The video of the Sumatran Tiger is outside of the mission and scope of the SIG.

A securitization is a form of financing. You pool little projects in Africa and Indonesia to get to a certain scale. These projects are typically off-grid solar projects. Pooling them is done by blockchain .
The video is a human interest story about projects that interest new members. As we have some from Indonesia, we chose the Sumatra Tiger.
@SherwoodMo @RobinKlemens We changed the video to be in a format like SiChen suggested, but a group one to accommodate more people!  These can go on member pages in the Wiki.
@knagware9 @RobinKlemens We looked at provisioning a Fabric v2.0 blockchain starting with 2 orgs and an Orderer.
This blockchain is at the Utility Emissions Level . A separate chain is needed for the Emissions Token Network based upon eThaler. We will build this and then see if we can join them.
Tigers negotiable:)
https://github.com/CA2SIGtestchainGRU/decentralized-energy-fabric-on-IBP20

If you could review the code and post your recommendations to GitHub in the form of issues, that would be great.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/climate-action-sig?msg=uPDJAh7J3SJ5JaQD5) Confirming that we will review the emissionscontract.js as reflected in the 'good first things' to do list (Wiki - Issue List)
We will look at the auto-testing and API from EIA as described in the issue list. We will not issue a PR until coordinating with @sichen . Thank you

We use this thread to coordinate the launch of the network.

https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/issues/112
@RobinKlemens Thank you for creating the issue and organising the threads. I created separate channels or threads based upon this good idea.
Normally I would make this comment in the Channel on Github. The issue is too technical for me, but I will handoever to Peter.

This is about performance. At some point there is the contemplated use of BESU. Would that be at the Emissions Token Network - Net Emissions Network Tier? If so, I will let Peter comment about Caliper. Thank  you.
I understand the immediate issue is the performance of emissioncontract.js .
The chaincode works. It's more a review. This is not time critical
What is time critical for you?
We have capacity.
At the moment I recommend to start with one of the good-first-issues. These are selected by @sichen . We can prioritize in the Peer Programming Call on Monday
@robertjames77 If you post a video outside the scope of the SIG, I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask you to take it down @robertjames77
(Related to the Sumatra tiger, of course ;) Member testimony is welcome as long as the focus is on the work and mission of the SIG).
OK, No group video!
The easier it is for members to onboard the better.
Thanks for your understanding :)

Sherwood, I care about the big picture here. When we are asked to bring in Stanford or COP26, and do so, then it is embarrassing to ask them to wait. If Si needs projects, then you have to go to Indonesia or Latin America to get them. That's all.

So, what would you like me to do with PandU of the Blockchain Indoneisa Society and Friends? Here, I can put together something in Bahasa, their native language. It is all about Si needing a project and I am here to help. Tigers notwithstanding.

Thanks Robert, I think just use your best judgement. As long as the content that we publish and the conversations that we have focus directly focused on the work of the SIG, then we are in good shape.
In the meantime, we can look at some of these programming issues as they are less ethereal.
Robert thank you for your help here.  If someone in Indonesia is interested in working with us, would they like to join a call, email our list so we can find out what they'd like?
The video idea is just to talk about the members of the group and what they're working on.  There are a lot of issues related to climate, but right now we need to focus a bit.
The focus is on the international climate conference and a project involving blockchain.
Robert I'm just confused.  What are you and your colleagues looking to do?  Are you looking to use our code to do a project?  Writing new code?
Yes, we have the entire blockchain society of indonesia and a couple from malaysia, plus bankers and others expert in Shari'a finance.
The confusion is because of separate email threads, no more.
I believe we share the same purpose. Simplicity. We have a 11 blockchains, 1 in production. Some of the 11 can be cannabalised based upon the code in Hyperledger Labs.
Rather than me type up stuff in a channel, why don't I send you a roadmap of one page!
That's great.  Would you like me to join one of your group meetings so I could talk about what we're doing and learn about what they're interested in?

@RobinKlemens organization: opentaps
OrdererEndpoints:
  - fabric-orderer.opentaps.net:443
AnchorPeers:
  - Host: fabric-peer.opentaps.net
    Port: 443

One question. I saw you committed *.pem and *.crt. Are they public keys ?

yes, they are just public keys and we need them for TLS communication and Fabric's MSP.
See:
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/it/release-2.2/create_channel/create_channel_config.html#organizations 
and
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/it/release-2.2/create_channel/create_channel_config.html#orderer

Last week, we launched our Hyperledger Fabric network running in two different Kubernetes clusters at the moment. We started with setting up the utility emissions channel (https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/CASIG/Utility+Emissions+Channel).

To check the current state of the network you can access https://explorer.emissionsaccounting.emitras.de/ (which is now secured with TLS)
Username: ca2sig
Password: ca2sig1234

If anyone wants to join the network, we have the readme ready for DigitalOcean and AWS EKS. The readme (https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/tree/main/multi-cloud-deployment)  helps you to set up a fabric network in one Kubernetes cluster. If all the tests pass you're ready to join our production-grade network. 
Looking forward to onboarding more organizations, chaincodes, and use cases.
Cheers,
Robin
@decentricity @kosasih A warm welcome to our community!  RR and others already joined.  We will have a project roadmap for you, introduction to the community and a tour of Blockchain Labs   Peter

Test our ontology against the simplest case of climate impact reporting, namely offsetting one's personal carbon footprint. We will discuss and compare two different methods for doing so. If you would like to prepare for the session, we suggest you look at the following two examples:

@RobinKlemens I'm working on `https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/issues/263`. The task list specifies saving the passphrase used for encryption inside the middleware. Do you mean storing it inside of `res.locals`?

@RobinKlemens I'm working on https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/blockchain-carbon-accounting/issues/263. The task list specifies saving the passphrase used for encryption inside the middleware. Do you mean storing it inside of `res.locals`?

@RobinKlemens I had 3 suggestions for the utility emissions project:
1. Migrate all cryptographic operations from crypto-js to node-forge, since Forge supports 512 bit keys, SHA3 hashing, and has higher performance over crypto-js. Native crypto (Node) may also be used to avoid external dependencies altogether.
2. Enforce a style guideline with a Linter such as ESLint and add a config file.
3. Improve visualizations by integrating something like Grafana, or we can even consider developing a Fabric plugin for Grafana (for Explorer perhaps).

Do let me know if you have suggestions! These are just a few ideas I had in mind.

Hello everyone,
I'm working on integrating a CI pipeline with GitHub actions to run the E2E tests on every pull request. However, I'm experiencing an unusual error during the step where the TypeScript app is run as part of running `./start.sh` in the `docker-compose-setup` directory:

`Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '../docker-compose-setup/organizations/peerOrganizations/auditor1.carbonAccounting.com/connection-auditor1.json'`

For your reference, here are the steps I'm running to set up the project:
`cd net-emissions-token-network/
npm ci
npx hardhat node --show-addresses &
cd ../utility-emissions-channel/docker-compose-setup/
./start.sh
`

I'm using Ubuntu 20.04 with Node v12.15.0 and npm v7.24.1 (I had to use a newer version of npm due to a bug in an earlier version of npm). I'm attaching the full server logs here as well for reference. If anyone has experienced this issue, I'd be really grateful if you could help me out.
